title: 110_hr7207
content: The Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008, also known as the "Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act," outlines the rights and responsibilities of federal entities in the spectrum relocation process. The Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008 amends the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act to provide payment for relocation costs to eligible federal entities operating government stations affected by frequency reallocation. Public information on the relocation process is also addressed in the Act. The Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008 amends the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act to require public notice of relocation plans by eligible Federal entities, including detailed transition plans and spectrum relocation requirements. The Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008 mandates eligible Federal entities to provide detailed transition plans for relocating current spectrum uses, including steps, timelines, interactions with NTIA, responsible staff, and plans for sharing frequencies with commercial licensees. The Federal entity must provide detailed transition plans for using relocation funds, procuring new equipment, field-testing new equipment, hiring contract personnel, and addressing risk factors in the relocation process to be eligible for payment from the Spectrum Relocation Fund. The Federal entity must submit transition plans to NTIA at least 60 days before they are made public. Plans will be evaluated by a 3-member Technical Panel within 30 days of submission to assess sufficiency, public information inclusion, and reasonableness of timelines and costs. The Director of OMB, the Administrator of NTIA, and the Chairman of the FCC will each appoint a radio engineer or technical expert to the Technical Panel. NTIA will establish regulations for the Panel's operations, and members will be appointed within 180 days of the Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008. If any required information is classified, the transition plan must explain its exclusion and provide relevant non-classified information. To be eligible for relocation cost payment from the Spectrum Relocation Fund, a Federal entity must include in its transition plan provisions for sharing and coordinating frequencies with commercial licensees. This includes accommodating the use of frequencies by commercial licensees. During the transition period, the Federal entity must share eligible frequencies with commercial licensees, be available for negotiation, and provide classified information to assist in the relocation process. To receive payment for relocation costs from the Spectrum Relocation Fund, a Federal entity must complete the relocation of its current spectrum uses within 1 year unless approved for a different timeline. The entity must provide an update of its transition plan to NTIA halfway through the relocation period. This process should not impact critical communications. Payments for relocation costs from the Spectrum Relocation Fund must be made to eligible Federal entities within 30 days after the grant of the first license following an auction. A dispute resolution process involving a 3-member board can be initiated if there are disputes over the execution, timing, or cost of the Federal entity's transition plan during the spectrum relocation process. The dispute resolution board will rule on disputes within 28 days. It will be assisted by the Technical Panel and governed by regulations set by NTIA. Appeals can be made to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit within 30 days. Each party is responsible for their own costs and expenses.
